DOC.HEAD: Titan Launch Delayed For the Seventh Time
DOC.TEXT: High winds aloft and low temperatures on the ground combined to force the seventh postponement of Martin Marietta's first commercial rocket launch _ but another try is set for tonight. Company officials reported winds about 30,000 feet above the launch area were too stiff Thursday and the temperature on the ground was too cool. The temperature must be at least 62 degrees for the launch of the Titan 3 rocket. That will preserve the resiliency of synthetic O-rings between joints in its two solid fuel rocket boosters. The rocket is to boost into orbit communications satellites for a Japanese company and British Ministry for Defense. The launch was rescheduled for 7:06 p.m. EST today. It was originally set for Dec. 7, but a combination of bad weather and technical problems resulted in repeated delays.
